results.title: Harriet the spy
results.creator_credit: Bronwen Hughes, Mary Kay Powell and Rastar Films
results.brief_description: 11 year old sixth grader Harriet M. Welsch (Michelle Trachtenberg) has an alter ego, she is a spy and aspiring writer who records all the goings on during her designated spy routes as well as her observations about her classmates: best friends Sport (Gregory Smith) and Janie (Vanessa Lee Chester), linked by a concealed tattoo and mutual dislike of class brat Marion Hawthorn. Isolated from her argumentative and absent parents, creative and observant Harriet finds solace in her writing and love with her nanny Ole Golly (Rosie O’Donnell). Harriet’s world is turned upside down when Golly leaves her family’s employment and her notebook is found and read, her private feelings about her friends exposed. Banned from writing, Harriet embarks on a revenge campaign against those who have bullied her since finding out what she really thinks of them, but revenge does not assuage her pain and she has to consider another way to gain forgiveness. At times an agonising coming of age film, the film does have a happy ending with a place for individuality and friendships are restored. Includes a cameo by Eartha Kitt as one of Harriet’s snooping accomplishments. Based on the successful novel by Louise Fitzhugh.

results.title: Rugrats in Paris: the movie = Rugrats II
results.creator_credit: Stig Bergqvist, Paul Demeyer, Gabor Csupo, Arlene Klasky, Rugrats Production KG, GmbH and Co and MFP Munich Film Partners GmbH
results.brief_description: When Angelica catches a few scenes from the “The Godfather” on television, she takes it upon herself to become the Bubfather and grants wishes to her fellow Rugrats. Chuckie’s wish is to have a new mother. Not long after, Stu Pickles receives an emergency call to travel to Europetarland, France, to repair a faulty Raptor and pacify rampaging theme park director, Coco LaBouche. He’s invited to bring family and friends for company and the Rugrats find themselves in Paris. In an effort to gain a promotion and become company president, the child hating Coco makes a play for Chuckie’s hapless father Chas in a desperate attempt to win favour with the outgoing President. Only Angelica knows of Coco’s cunning plan and it’s up to the Rugrats to save Chas, imperilling a few famous landmarks along the way. Humorous throughout, the film has a strong sense of familial values and what constitutes “good” parenting. Features the voices of Susan Sarandon, John Lithgow, Debbie Reynolds, Christine Cavanaugh, Elizabeth Daily and Cheryl Chase.

results.title: The Eagle has landed [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: John Sturges, David Niven Jr, Jack Wiener and ITC Entertainment
results.brief_description: A Colonel with the Luftwaffe, imprisoned for striking a fellow officer, is offered a lifeline when Nazi Colonel Radl (Robert Duvall) asks him to lead a daring suicide mission to kidnap Winston Churchill. Radl has received direct orders from Heinrich Himmler (Donald Pleasance), who in turn, has been instructed by Hitler himself. The PM is known to be holidaying in Norfolk, so recently released prisoner Karl Steiner (Michael Caine) and his men parachute into Sudley Constable, a small village nearby, camouflaged as Polish allies. The sixteen man team comprises of a motley crew of stereotypes, including a honey voiced IRA man Liam Devlin (Donald Sutherland), who dupes a young girl on horseback (Jenny Agutter) - one of the few women in the film. After an incident in which one of his men saves the life of a local boy, their mission is jeopardised when the rescuer is killed and his Nazi identity revealed beneath the Polish garb. Steiner and his men take refuge in a Church as they await the arrival of Churchill to complete the Fuhrer’s orders. Based on the Jack Higgins novel, this was the last film John Sturges (The Great escape, The Magnificent seven) directed before his death in 1992. Cast also includes Anthony Quayle, Jean Marsh, Treat Williams and Larry Hagman. Screenplay by Tom Mankiewicz.

results.title: The Elephant man [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David Lynch, Jonathan Sanger and Brooksfilms
results.brief_description: Deformed at birth by a rare disease, penniless John Merrick is forced to become the star attraction in a travelling freak-show. Treves, a compassionate surgeon, rescues him from the fairground taunts, coaxing out of the terrified, disabled man a touchingly unembittered personality. This multi-award winning film stars Anthony Hopkins, John Hurt, John Gielgud and Anne Bancroft. Based on “The Elephant man and other reminiscences” by Sir Frederick Treves and in part on “The Elephant man: a study in human dignity” by Ashley Montagu. Cast includes John Hurt, Anthony Hopkins, Anne Bancroft, John Gielgud, Wendy Hiller

results.title: Raging bull [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Robert Chartoff, Irwin Winkler and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Film biography of New York boxer Jack La Motta, a one-time middleweight boxing champion who ended up an alcoholic running a sleazy Bronx nightclub. Traces Jake La Motta’s years of success in the forties to his humiliation in the fifties, ending with his career as a nightclub entertainer in 1964. This is not a conventional bio-pic with an explanatory approach to character. The exterior drama is displaced by La Motta’s struggle with interior demons. A radical awareness inflects the modes of the bio-pic and film noir, through the fractured structure, to link aggression with sexual repression and the denial of self with redemption. Robert De Niro gives an outstanding performance as the violent and inarticulate La Motta who pursues the “American Dream” the only way he knows how: through his fists. In “Raging bull” Scorsese continues his obsession with the dark side of the urban American psyche and the result is a largely pessimistic but passionate piece of filmmaking. The boxing sequences are operatic in their violent excess and not for weak stomachs. Despite numerous Oscar nominations (and a Best Actor win for De Niro) the film received a mixed critical reaction and performed poorly at the box-office. Currently however, “Raging bull” is considered a masterpiece of American cinema.

results.title: Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, David L. Wolper, Stan Margulies, Quaker Oats Company and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description: This funny and inventive screenplay by Roald Dahl is based upon his best-seller “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” Gene Wilder is at his zany best as Willy Wonka, owner of a world-famous sweet factory who offers the fabulous prize of a tour of his extraordinary premises to five lucky children. However, when the winners arrive to claim their reward, they are caught up in a series of incredible and exciting adventures as Willy Wonka tests their honesty. The Academy Award nominated soundtrack includes the hit “Candy Man”.

results.title: Minority report
results.creator_credit: Steven Spielberg, Walter Parkes, Gerald Molen, Bonnie Curtis, Jan De Bont, Cruise-Wagner Productions, Blue Tulip, Amblin Entertainment, NBCUniversal and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In the near future a scientist (Max Von Sydow) has created a perfect system by which to end murder. By utilising the psychic abilities of “precogs”—three individuals who have been rendered schizophrenic by being born to drug-addicted mothers—he can identify killers before they commit their crimes. The Precrime Unit, led by the zealous John Anderton (Tom Cruise), whose son was abducted years ago, has resulted in the apparent end of homicide in Washington DC. But on the eve of Precrime going national, John Anderton finds himself in an accidental encounter with one of the precogs, Agatha (Samantha Morton), which leads to his name being revealed as a future murderer. With only one day and night in which to prove his “innocence”, Anderton kidnaps Agatha and searches for the true secrets underlying the miracle of Precrime judgement. Based on a short fiction by Philip K. Dick, “Minority Report” is a darkly dystopic vision of the future. Echoing Ridley Scott’s “Blade Runner” in presenting a world divided into enclaves of privilege and vast slums of poverty and crime, the film works best in realistically conveying the architecture, technology and domiciles of a possible future. In this, Spielberg is assisted by state-of-the-art special effects and a wizard art production team. Spielberg’s career-long obsession with reconstituting the nuclear family finally delivers a narrative arc which differs wildly from Dick’s much bleaker vision. But for all his Capraesque desire for closure and hope, what remains with the viewer is the horror of a society which has abrogated to science the role of judgement, and which has therefore nullified the meaning of free will. This two disc special edition of “Minority Report” features a second disc with over an hour of special features. The film also stars Colin Farrell.

results.title: Snapshot = Day after Halloween = Day before Halloween [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Simon Wincer, Antony Ginnane, William Fayman, Barbi Taylor and Australian International Film Corporation
results.brief_description: For his film debut director Simon Wincer chose to tread the well-chartered territory of the horror thriller, in which the life for an innocent character is irretrievably changed through a combination of naivety and bad encounters. Angela, a young hairdresser with modelling ambitions, is talked into posing nude for a photo in order to attract attention. Soon enough, the attention is transformed in stalking, complete with the discovery of a pig’s head in her bed. Of the sleazy producer, the eccentric magazine producer and the clingy ex-boyfriend — who wants Angela dead and why? Reference: Greg Kerr ‘Australian Film’ (Scott Murray ed.) Oxford University Press, 1995: p. 47.

results.title: All that jazz [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Bob Fosse, Robert A Aurthur and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Joe Gideon is a chain-smoking, pill popping workaholic obsessed with producing, directing and choreographing a Broadway musical while womanising and editing his latest film (actually Fosse’s own film “Lenny”). This semi-autobiographical musical drama is framed by Gideon’s conversations with a mysterious figure of nemesis the “Lady in White”. Following Gideon’s heart attack, the film assumes a surreal hallucinatory logic. Not only does Fosse borrow freely from the European classics “8 1/2” and “The Seventh seal” but he inverts the showbiz and life affirming “That’s entertainment” ethos of the traditional musical. Cast includes Roy Scheider, Jessica Lange, Ann Reinking and John Lithgow. Awards: Winner, Best Art Direction, Costume Design, Editing, Best Score, Academy Awards, 1979.

results.title: Swingers
results.creator_credit: Doug Liman, Victor Simpkins, Miramax Films and Independent Pictures
results.brief_description: A hip, urban comedy of manners about male friendship, dating and the fantastically labyrinthine rules of how to stay cool in LA. Directed by Doug Liman (Go, The Bourne Identity), this film catapulted into the spotlight actors Jon Favreau (who also wrote the screenplay) and Vince Vaughn. Mike (Favreau), an out of work actor and comedian, is lovesick for his long-term girlfriend who he hasn’t heard from in six months. Buoyed in his misery by friends Trent, Rob and Sue, Mike is taken to a slew of groovy LA bars and parties in the hope that he’ll meet a babe and be jolted out of his despair. Trent (Vaughn) is Mike’s most confident and smooth talking friend, a sartorial charmer who has a way with the ladies and is constantly on the make. Mike struggles with the convoluted courtship rules, whilst battling his extensive self-doubts and self-consciousness. “Swingers” works as a sharp satire of the LA scene where bit actors scrape by on the glory of call-backs for pilots and former glories are regurgitated in the hope of getting lucky in love. With a warm, energetic quality, and a talky, funny script, the film regales the audience with memorable characters and hilarious scenarios.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Doug Liman, Victor Simpkins, Miramax Films and Independent Pictures
